awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Systematic Comparative and Historical Analysis Framework for Social Movements
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop methods for studying online social movements that are playing increasingly influential roles.  Despite its promise, research using social media data has suffered from a number of shortcomings including lack of representativeness, incompleteness, and the difficulty of identifying relevant outcome variables. Such shortcomings are widely acknowledged, yet their solutions have proven elusive.  This project makes intellectual contributions to these issues at both the data collection and data labeling steps.  this project will improve our understanding of how online movements are formed, how they evolve over time, how the participants coordinate, and how movements change their participants and the broader public.  This study will inform community organizers and citizens of strategies that result in desirable outcomes in civic participation, the designers of online platforms that aim to support such civic engagement about which design choices lead to what type of civic engagement, and journalists that aim to provide accurate narratives of online social movements. The project will also have educational impact, as the datasets will be used in data science courses and will be shared with the broader research community.
 
The main goals of this research are to propose methods for optimizing data collection strategies; present methods for optimizing data labeling; analyze the development, coordination, and success for social movements of varying scales under different data collection and labeling schemes; and model determinants of protest participation and movement success using curated data. At the data collection step, the project will contribute: a systematic evaluation of the social media data collection methods used in related work; the formulation of topology-based and content-based data collection strategies; and the development of methods to perform effective iterative data collection given a set of possible strategies, through modeling to maximize the expected reward earned through a sequence of choices made in a system of learning problems. At the data labeling step, the project will contribute the development of cross-domain text classification methods to perform cost-effective data labeling through crowdsourcing platforms, and new insights about the potential for transfer learning across popular social media platforms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed innovative methodologies for studying online social movements, addressing longstanding challenges in contentious studies scholarship. Due to the difficulty of collecting, labeling, and processing large amounts of data, past work has largely focused on single case studies, limiting the generalizability of findings. We addressed these challenges through computational approaches and produced methodological insights, theoretical advancements, and practical tools listed below.

Methodological insights related data collection: A major contribution of the project was the development of social media data collection methods to study social movements. We systematically evaluated diverse collection pipelines across a diverse set of social movements with varying activity levels. Our research demonstrated the effectiveness of embedding-based methods during normal activity periods and highlighted the benefits of combining multiple approaches during peak mobilization periods to improve data coverage. These methods addressed critical gaps in data representativeness, particularly during high-activity periods when diverse participant groups create a wide variety of content.

Methodological insights related to data labeling: The project leveraged machine learning techniques, including state-of-the-art transformer-based models, to develop cost-effective and scalable methods for data labeling. These methods were applied to categorize messages participants share about social movement into framing types (e.g., whether the message is identifying a problem, proposing a solution, or aiming to motivate people to participate in collective action). Our scalable approach allows us to categorize large amounts of data, which enables a detailed examination of frames, how they are constructed, and how they affect how the audience responds to a message.

We also developed scalable machine learning techniques to determine whether a social media user participating in a movement is an individual, social movement organization (SMO), or other organization. This allowed us to determine the contribution of different account types to movement success across multiple movements. Our scalable solution has various advantages compared to past work. For instance, past work only examined well-known large SMOs due to the difficulty to identifying the long tail of small organizations. In comparison, our approach identified over 50K organizations that participated in the Black Lives Matter and women’s right movements. Our analysis reveals that small organizations indeed behave differently compared to extensively studied large SMOs, highlighting the biases inherent in past approaches.
